{{Main|Windows 8}}
{{Main|Windows 8}}
â
Windows 8 is the upcoming version of Microsoft Windows, scheduled for release in fall 2012. It was first mentioned at the 2011 [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in Las Vegas, where Microsoft announced that it would include support for system-on-a-chip and mobile [[ARM architecture|ARM processors]]. On 1 June 2011, Microsoft officially unveiled the operating system at Computex 2011. The redesigned user interface in this release was designed to accommodate a variety of devices and screen sizes, in a departure from the previous Windows focus on personal computers.<ref>http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2011/jun11/06-01corporatenews.aspx</ref> On the Building Windows 8 blog, it was announced that a computer running Windows 8 can boot up much faster than Windows 7.<ref name="Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.winsupersite.com/blog/supersite-blog-39/windows8/microsoft-touts-incredible-windows-8-boot-times-140515 | title=Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times | publisher=Penton Media | accessdate=September 09, 2011 | author=Thurott, Paul}}</ref>
+
Windows 8 is the upcoming version of Microsoft Windows, scheduled for release in fall 2012. It was first mentioned at the 2011 [[Consumer Electronics Show]] in Las Vegas, where Microsoft announced that it would include support for system-on-a-chip and mobile [[ARM architecture|ARM processors]]. On 1 June 2011, Microsoft officially unveiled the operating system at Computex 2011. The redesigned user interface in this release was designed to accommodate a variety of devices and screen sizes, in a departure from the previous Windows focus on personal computers.<ref>http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2011/jun11/06-01corporatenews.aspx</ref> On the Building Windows 8 blog, it was announced that a computer running Windows 8 can boot up much faster than Windows 7.<ref name="Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times">{{cite web | url=http://www.winsupersite.com/blog/supersite-blog-39/windows8/microsoft-touts-incredible-windows-8-boot-times-140515 | title=Microsoft Touts Incredible Windows 8 Boot Times | publisher=Penton Media | accessdate=September 09, 2011 | author=Thurott, Paul}}</ref> New features also include [[USB 3.0]] support, the Windows App Store, the ability to run from USB drives with [[Windows To Go]], and others. (See: [[Features new to Windows 8]])
A first public glipse of Windows Server 8 was also shown by Microsoft at the 2011 Microsoft Worldwide Partner Conference.<ref>[http://www.zdnet.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-shows-off-early-peek-at-windows-server-8/10002?tag=content;search-results-river Microsoft shows off early peek at Windows Server 8].</ref>
A first public glipse of Windows Server 8 was also shown by Microsoft at the 2011 Microsoft Worldwide Partner Conference.<ref>[http://www.zdnet.com/blog/microsoft/microsoft-shows-off-early-peek-at-windows-server-8/10002?tag=content;search-results-river Microsoft shows off early peek at Windows Server 8].</ref>
